Scheme 1 Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 over a novel MOF- derived MnOx catalyst Ruiyang Chen Investigation Writing – original draft a b Xiaoyu Fang Investigation a b Zhenguo Li Formal analysis c Zhiming Liu Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China b Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Environmental Catalysis, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Environmental Catalysis, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Environmental Catalysis, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China c National Engineering Laboratory for Mobile Source Emission Control Technology, China Automotive Technology & Research Center, Tianjin 300300, China National Engineering Laboratory for Mobile Source Emission Control Technology, China Automotive Technology & Research Center Tianjin 300300 China National Engineering Laboratory for Mobile Source Emission Control Technology, China Automotive Technology & Research Center, Tianjin 300300, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China. State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China A novel MnOx catalyst (Mn-MP) derived from MOF-Mn3(BTC)2(H2O)6 was fabricated and investigated for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 at low temperatures. Mn-MP catalyst showed a superior activity and noticeably improved tolerance to SO2. The MOF precursor and doping PVP led to large surface area, small particle size and more crystalline defects of Mn-MP catalyst. The formation of abundant acid sites, Mn4+ and surface chemical oxygen would promote the NH3-SCR reaction. In situ DRIFTs demonstrated the high SO2 tolerance over the Mn-MP catalyst not only results from the reduced irreversible sulfurization rate, but also the promoting adsorption of active bidentate nitrates and NH4 + in the coexistence of sulfates. Our work shed light on the design of porous MOF-derived MnOx catalysts with high SO2 resistance at low temperatures. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Nitrogen oxides NH3-SCR MOF-derived MnOx 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx) emission from stationary sources and vehicle exhaust can cause serious environmental issues, such as the formation of photochemical smog and acid rain, and is very harmful to human health [1–3]. Different methods have been developed to control NOx emission, and selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is considered to be one of the most efficient technologies [4,5]. For the NH3-SCR process, the highly active catalyst plays a key role in the removal of NOx. Nowadays, the commercial catalyst for the NH3-SCR of NOx is mainly V2O5-WO3 (MoO3)/TiO2, whose active temperature window is 300 ~ 400 °C [4]. V has a toxic effect on the ecological environment, and this catalyst is efficient only when it is placed upstream of the electric precipitator. However, the catalyst is susceptible to be deactivated due to the massive dust and the high concentration of SO2 [6]. Therefore, it is urgent to develop a highly active NH3-SCR catalyst at low temperatures (< 200 °C), which then can be installed after the electric precipitator. In this way, the lifetime of the NH3-SCR catalyst can be prolonged and the economy of the SCR process can be improved. To develop active low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts, various transition metals have been investigated [7–11]. MnOx has attracted much attention owing to its environmental friendliness and high redox capacity [12–17], but they still face big challenges in SO2 resistance. It is generally accepted that the formation of (NH4)2SO4/NH4HSO4 and MnSO4 caused by SO2 oxidation are the primary reasons for catalyst deactivation [4,7]. Therefore, reducing the adsorption/oxidation of SO2 could be an effective approach to improve the SO2 tolerance. From the perspective of acidic/basic properties, enhancing the acidity of catalysts could reduce the SO2 adsorption to some extent [4], and it was further confirmed that the Brønsted (B)-acid sites rather than the Lewis (L)-acid sites contribute to the strong resistance to SO2 poisoning [18]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived metal oxides can not only introduce B acid sites, but also promote the high dispersion of acid sites due to their high porosity and large specific surface areas [19–24]. It was reported that MnxCo3−xO4 nanocages derived from the MOF of Mn3[Co(CN)6]2·nH2O exhibited much better SO2 tolerance at low temperatures, which was ascribed to the hierarchically porous structure, larger number of active sites and strong interaction between MnOx and CoOx [24]. However, the role of B acid sites in SO2 resistance hasn’t been addressed and the toxic cyanide ligands are used during the preparation, which is not friendly to the environment. Considering that 1,3,5-trimesic acid (H3BTC) is a cheap and green multidentate ligand, and the structure of MOFs can be regulated by the addition of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), herein, we designed a novel porous MnOx catalyst (Mn-MP) by using Mn-H3BTC as a precursor and PVP as a structure-directing agent. This catalyst was active for the reduction of NOx by NH3 at low temperatures, and also showed high SO2 tolerance. The reasons for the high activity and strong SO2 resistance have been revealed by in situ DRIFTs studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of Mn-MP: A proper amount of Mn(CH3COO)2.4 H2O and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, 6.43 g) were dissolved in deionized water, then stirred to get the solution A. 1,3,5-trimesic acid (H3BTC, 18 mmol, 3.78 g) was dissolved in 30 ml N, N-dimethylformamide to form solution B. Subsequently, Solution A was directly added into solution B, the mixed solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and held at 110 °C for 24 h. The precipitate was filtered, washed, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. Then the solid was calcined in air at 300 °C for 4 h (see Scheme 1). The synthesis of Mn-M is similar to that of Mn-MP except PVP is absent in solution A. The Mn-A was also prepared through direct decomposition of Mn(CH3COO)2.4 H2O at 300 °C for 4 h in air. 2.2 Catalytic performance test The catalytic performance was tested in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with a 0.12 g catalyst. The reaction conditions were as follows: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5 vol% H2O (when used), 50 ppm SO2 (when used), and N2 balance. The gas flow rate is 300 cm3·min−1, corresponding to the gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 140,000 h−1. The concentration of effluent gas was analyzed online by chemiluminescence NO/NO2 analyzer (Thermo Scientific, model 42i-HL) and a FITR spectrometer (Gasmet FTIR DX4000). The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated as follows: NO x conversion = NO x in - NO x out [NO x ] in × 100 N 2 selectivity = NO x in + NH 3 in - NO x out - NH 3 out - 2 N 2 O out NO x in - NO x out + NH 3 in - NH 3 out × 100 The reaction rate (K) for NH3-SCR of NOx was obtained using the differential reactor over which the NOx conversion was kept below 20%, it was calculated as following formula (1). And the Ea can be obtained from the formula (2). (1) K( μmol / g·s ) = F Y NOx C NOx m cat (2) ln K = - Ea RT + ln A Where F is the total molar flow rate (μmol s−1), YNOx is the molar fraction of NOx in the feed, CNOx is the conversion of NOx, and mcat is the weight of catalyst (g). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE system with Cu Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 449 C instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in an air atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on the electron spectrometer (VG Scientific, ESCALab220i-XL) with Mg Kα radiation, in which C 1 s signal (284.8 eV) was used as the reference. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken by a Hitachi S-4800 instrument. Texture properties were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms collected on the micrometric ASAP 2010 instrument. Both temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) were conducted on a Micrometrics Chemisorb 2720 analyzer, 0.1 g of catalysts was first pretreated with N2 at 300 °C, then for the H2-TPR experiment, the temperature was raised to 700 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C·min-1 in 10% H2/N2 flow. In the case of NH3-TPD experiment, the temperature was raised to 700 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C·min-1 in N2 flow after the catalyst was saturated by NH3/N2 flow at 100 °C. The H2 consumption or NH3 desorption with temperature was recorded continuously by the TCD detector. In-situ DRIFTs were recorded on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer. The sample was first pretreated in N2 flow at 300 °C for 1 h, then take the background spectrum at the desired temperature. The sample spectrum was obtained by subtracting the corresponding background spectrum [24]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance The catalytic performance of Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts are investigated and the NOx conversions are shown in Fig. 1. The conversion of NOx over the Mn-A catalyst is less than 80% below 175 °C. Compared with the Mn-A catalyst, both Mn-M and Mn-MP samples are more active for the NH3-SCR of NOx, and the Mn-MP is the most active catalyst, over which more than 85% NOx conversion can be achieved between 100 and 200 °C. This fact indicates that the MOF-derived samples can significantly boost the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity and the introduction of PVP in the MOF preparation process can further enhance the activity. Over the CeO2-MnOx (5:5) catalyst derived from the Ce-Mn coordination polymer, the NO conversion was lower than 80% below 200 °C [19]. In the case of MnOx prepared from the Mn-MOF-74, the conversion can’t reach 98% until the temperature increased to 220 °C [22]. Therefore, the catalytic activity of the Mn-MP catalyst in this work is superior to those reported previously [19,22]. In addition, the N2 selectivity (See Fig. S1) over the three catalysts also follows the order of Mn-MP > Mn-M > Mn-A. The main by-product is N2O, which results from the excess oxidation of NH3 species due to the strong oxidation ability of MnOx catalyst [4]. Fig. 2 shows the temperature dependence of NH3-SCR reaction rate constant over Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts. It is found that the apparent activation energies (Ea) of the three catalysts decrease in the order of Mn-A > Mn-M > Mn-MP. This means NH3-SCR of NOx reaction proceeds more easily over the Mn-MP catalyst. The tolerance to H2O or SO2 is important for the practical application of the NH3-SCR catalyst. From Fig. 1, the NOx conversions of the catalysts at 175 °C were lower than 100%, which can eliminate the effect of supersaturation [25]. Thus the impacts of H2O or SO2 on Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts were investigated at 175 °C and the results are illustrated in Fig. 3. We can see that the inhibition trend by H2O is reversible for all three catalysts, while the reversibility of SO2 poisoning depends on the catalyst. For Mn-A, the introduction of H2O or SO2 led to a remarkable decrease in the activity, and the activity can’t recover after cutting off the SO2. In contrast, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts showed excellent H2O or SO2 resistance, the NOx conversion can be maintained above 80% and 90%, respectively, and their activities can be restored when SO2 is excluded. After introduction of 50 ppm SO2 at 180 °C, the NOx conversion decreased with time over the Co7Mn3Ox catalyst prepared by the co-precipitation method [15]. And the NOx conversion over MnFeDy-0.1 dropped from 85% to 30% within 5 h, and then recovered to 40% after cutting off SO2 [26]. Compared with those low-temperature catalysts, the MOF-derived Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts showed higher SO2 tolerance. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 XRD analysis XRD patterns of the Mn-MP and its precursor, Mn-M and Mn-A catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. The precursor of Mn-MP has the characteristic peaks assigned to Mn3(BTC)2(H2O)6 [7], suggesting the MOF-Mn was successfully synthesized. The crystal structure of Mn-MP differs from its precursor but presents active species of Mn3O4 (PDF#80–0382) and Mn2O3 (PDF#78–0390), indicating the complete removal of organic ligands and the transition from MOF to metal oxides. Mn-A mainly exhibits the characteristic peaks of MnO (PDF#71–1177) and hausmannite Mn3O4, while both the Mn-MP and Mn-M catalysts are dominated by Mn3O4 and Mn2O3. These results suggest that the MOF template can regulate the existence form of MnOx, and boost the formation of MnOx with higher valence states of Mn, which could contribute to their high low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. What’s more, it can be observed that the peak intensity of the Mn-MP catalyst is weaker than that of the Mn-M catalyst, indicating the particle size of Mn-MP is smaller than that of Mn-M and contains more defects, which is conducive to the activity of NH3-SCR catalysts [27]. 3.2.2 SEM analysis The morphology and structure of the studied samples were depicted by SEM (See Fig. 5). Mn-A shows a stack of particles with different sizes, and many particles are agglomerated into the solid block (Fig. 5(a)), which may lead to its smaller specific surface area and inferior activity for the NH3-SCR. The precursor of Mn-M has a structure composed of nanorods that are in an untidy pile (See Fig. 5(b)). After calcination, Mn-M is like porous monoliths and there are macropores between monoliths (See Fig. 5(c)). In comparison, the precursor of Mn-MP presents a neatly arranged belt structure (See Fig. 5(d)), which results from the structural direction of PVP through the interaction with metal ions [24,27]. After calcination, Mn-MP is composed of a 3D interconnected porous grid (See Fig. 5(e)). 3.2.3 N2 adsorption N2 physisorption isotherms of Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP are displayed in Fig. S2. All samples show typical IV-type curves with an H3 type hysteresis loop over P/P0 between 0.8 and 0.95, indicating the presence of mesopores [21]. And the mesopores have broad pore size distributions (Fig. S2, inset). The specific BET surface area and total pore volume (Vt) of Mn-MP (51 m2/g and 0.5 cm3/g) and Mn-M (58 m2/g and 0.6 cm3/g) are much larger than Mn-A (19 m2/g and 0.13 cm3/g), which results from their porous structures. The porous structures with larger specific surface area are propitious to the exposure of active sites and the adsorption of reactants, affording the excellent catalytic activities of MOF-derived MnOx catalysts. 3.2.4 XPS analysis The surface composition and chemical nature of the catalysts are further investigated by XPS analysis (See Fig. 6). The peak of Mn 2p3/2 (See Fig. 6a) could be deconvoluted into three peaks centered at ~ 640.9 eV, 642.1 eV, and 643.4 eV, which are attributed to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively [28,29]. The ratio of Mn4+ over the three catalysts is decreased in the order of Mn-MP (25%) > Mn-M (21%) > Mn-A (19%). For O 1 s spectra (See Fig. 6b), it can be deconvoluted into two peaks: ~ 530 eV and 531.4 eV, which are ascribed to the lattice oxygen (denoted as OL) and surface oxygen (O2- or O- due to defect or hydroxyl-like group, denoted as OS), respectively [26,30]. The OS ratio over the three catalysts decreases in the order of Mn-MP (28%) > Mn-M (25%) > Mn-A (22%). It has been demonstrated that OS species are more active than OL species due to their higher mobility. In the process of calcination during the catalyst preparation, not only the MOF frameworks but also the structure of manganese acetate would undergo distortion with increasing the structure strain and reconstruction by relieving this strain, leading to the formation of -OH group [16,18,27]. Therefore, the amount of -OH could depend on the distortion extent of the structure in pyrolysis, which is significantly affected by the size of the removable ligands. It is obvious that the size of the three ligands follows the order of PVP > H3BTC > > HAc. Therefore, the Mn-MP catalyst can possess the most amount of -OH even though its surface area is slightly lower than that of Mn-M. A larger amount of surface -OH group could act as B acid sites to enhance the chemisorption of NH3 [24]. Both the Mn4+ and OS species are beneficial for the high activity in the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures via enhancing the oxidation of NO to NO2 [31–33]. It is evident that the fraction of OS correlates with the Mn4+/Mn ratio, which is in line with the results reported previously [29,34–36]. By quantitative correlation of the ratio of Mn4+/Mn with the reaction rate at 110 °C (See Fig. 7), it can be concluded that the reaction rate constant (K) increases linearly with increasing the Mn4+/Mn ratio, indicating that the Mn4+ plays a key role for the excellent low-temperature activity. Therefore, the enrichment of the Mn4+ and OS on the Mn-MP catalysts results in its superior low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. 3.2.5 H2-TPR analysis The redox performances of the three catalysts are investigated using H2-TPR, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. For all the catalysts, there are two main reduction peaks. The former one (low temperature) is ascribed to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and the latter one (high temperature) is assigned to the reduction of Mn2O3 to MnO [37,38]. Compared with the Mn-A sample, not only both the reduction peaks of Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts are much larger but also the high-temperature one shifts to the lower temperature, suggesting the improved reducibility and oxygen mobility of Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts [3], which contributes to their excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. 3.2.6 NH3-TPD analysis It is well acknowledged that the chemisorption and activation of NH3 on acid sites is crucial in the NH3-SCR reaction [29,30]. Then the acid amount of Mn-A and Mn-MP catalysts was investigated by the NH3-TPD experiment and the results are shown in Fig. 9. Both samples display a broad NH3 desorption band from 100 to 650 °C (See Fig. 9(a)), which can be divided into three desorption peaks. The desorption peaks below 200 °C, between 200 and 300 °C, and above 300 °C could be attributed to weak, medium and strong absorbed NH3, respectively [17]. NH4 + bound to B acid sites are usually more thermally unstable than NH3 coordinated to L acid sites. Thus, the weak acid sites are associated with B acid sites while the strong acid sites are due to L acid sites, and the medium acid sites could be related to B and L acid sites [29,31,33]. Fig. 9(b) shows the quantitative analyses of NH3-TPD. There are nearly no weak acid sites on the Mn-A, indicating the absence of B acid sites, while the MOF-derived Mn-MP is conducive to the formation of B acid sites as well as L acid sites, and the amount of acid sites on the Mn-MP is significantly enhanced. 3.3 In situ DRIFTs studies 3.3.1 Adsorption of pyridine The DRIFT spectra of pyridine adsorption on Mn-A and Mn-MP at 175 °C were illustrated in Fig. 10. Over Mn-A catalyst the bands corresponding to L acid sites at 1478 and 1443 cm−1 [9,39] were observed. Compared with Mn-A, over Mn-MP catalyst the intensities of the peaks ascribed to L acid sites are increased, and the band corresponding to B acid site appeared at 1541 cm−1 [9]. Therefore, both L and B acid sites are present over Mn-MP catalyst. 3.3.2 Adsorption and reactivity of NH3 species Fig. 11 shows the in situ DRIFTs of NH3 adsorption over the Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts at 175 °C. The bands located at ~1605, 1267 and 1190 cm−1 are assigned to the coordinately NH3 related to L acid sites [39–41], while the peak at ~1500 cm−1 can be ascribed to the NH4 + species on B acid sites [34,42]. There are only L acid sites (1190 cm−1) on the Mn-A catalyst, while except for the adsorbed NH3 species on the L acid sites (1190, 1605 and 1267 cm−1), the NH3 species adsorbed on B acid sites (1500 cm−1) is also detected over the Mn-MP and Mn-M catalysts. And it is noted that the peak area of NH3 species of the three catalysts follows the order of Mn-MP ≈ Mn-M > > Mn-A, which is consistent with the NH3-TPD analysis. The reactivity of pre-adsorbed NH3 with NO + O2 was investigated at 175 °C over the Mn-MP catalyst, and the results are presented in Fig. S3. After NH3 is introduced for 30 min and then purged with N2, several peaks (1605, 1500, 1267 and 1190 cm−1) attributed to the adsorbed NH3 species appear [40–42]. When switching to NO + O2, it is observed that the intensities of bands ascribed to the adsorbed NH3 species on L acid sites (1605, 1267 and 1190 cm−1) decrease and finally disappear with increasing time, meanwhile, some bands assigned to the surface nitrate species (~1546, 1525, 1246 and 1005 cm−1) appear, indicating that these adsorbed NH3 species on L acid sites are main reactive species. 3.3.3 Adsorption and reactivity of NOx species Fig. 12 shows the DRIFTs of NO + O2 adsorption on the Mn-A, Mn-M and Mn-MP catalysts at 175 °C. The peaks located at ~1629, 1559, 1246 and 1011 cm−1 are assigned to gaseous NO2 molecules [43], bidentate nitrate [44], bridged nitrate [45,46] and trans-(N2O2)2− species [30], respectively. Peak intensities over the Mn-MP catalyst are higher than those over the Mn-M catalyst, followed by the Mn-A catalyst. These results confirm that more NOx can be adsorbed and activated over the Mn-MP catalyst due to its high oxidation ability. The reactions of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2 over Mn-MP catalysts were recorded at 175 °C by in-situ DRIFTs, and the dynamic changes are illustrated in Fig. S4. After being exposed to NO + O2 for 60 min and then purged with N2, the Mn-MP catalysts were mainly covered by bidentate nitrate (1559 cm−1) [43,44] and bridged nitrate (1246 cm−1) [45,46]. When the gas was switched to NH3, the peak intensity of bidentate nitrate decreased rapidly compared to that of bridged nitrate, and meanwhile, the peak intensities of the adsorbed NH3 species (1606, 1496 and 1272 cm−1) increased. These results indicate that the main active intermediate over the Mn-MP is the bidentate nitrate. 3.3.4 In situ DRIFTs analyses of SO2 resistance To reveal the high SO2 resistance of Mn-MP, the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO + O2 over the SO2 + O2 pre-adsorbed Mn-MP and Mn-A catalysts were recorded by in-situ DRIFTs. Fig. 13 showed the in situ DRIFTs of SO2 + O2 adsorption over Mn-A and Mn-MP catalyst at 175 °C (The corresponding spectra collected at specified times are shown in Fig. S5). As shown in Fig. 13, there are mainly four adsorbed SO2 species over Mn-A catalyst, those are, 1336, 1261, 1125 and 996 cm−1 corresponding to coordinated sulfate species, asymmetric stretching vibration mode of O-S-O species of HSO4 -, bulk metal sulfate, and symmetric stretching vibration of O-S-O, respectively [47–49]. Over the Mn-MP catalyst, besides the above four adsorbed SO2 species located on 1334, 1251, 1092 and 993 cm−1, there are other two peaks of 1618 and 1544 cm−1, which are ascribed to the adsorbed HSO4 - generated by the interaction between SO2 and surface hydroxyl groups [47–49]. Notably, the peak intensity of bulk metal sulfate over the Mn-A catalyst increases markedly with time and finally is dominated on the catalyst, while that over the Mn-MP catalyst changes little and the final main sulfate species is HSO4 -, implying that the B acid sites such as hydroxyl groups can adsorb SO2 preferentially and form HSO4 -. To further reveal the poisoning effect of bulk sulfate and HSO4 - on the catalysts, the NO and NH3 adsorption DRIFTs experiments on SO2-poisoned Mn-A and Mn-MP catalysts were conducted, and the results are shown in Fig. S6 and Fig. S7, respectively. We can see that there are almost no peaks of NO or NH3 species over the SO2-poisoned Mn-A sample (S-Mn-A) (See Fig. S6 (a) and Fig. S7 (a)), indicating the Mn-A was inactivated irreversibly by the bulk MnSO4, which is in accordance with previous studies [47–49]. By contrast, there are still many adsorbed active NOx and NH3 species detected over SO2-poisoned Mn-MP catalysts (S-Mn-MP). As shown in Fig. S6 (b), the adsorbed NOx species over the S-Mn-MP catalyst are similar to those over the fresh Mn-MP catalyst and the bidentate nitrate is also the dominated species. The little effect of SO2 on the adsorption of NOx can be ascribed to the preferential adsorption of SO2 by surface hydroxyl groups so that the redox sites are free from the attack of SO2. For most catalysts, improving the adsorption of active NOx with the coexistence of sulfates is difficult because there is competition adsorption on the redox sites between NO and SO2 [4]. Nowadays the strategies to solve this problem focus on modifying the catalysts with another metal element, such as Eu [50], Zr [51], Ni and Co [52]. However, by pyrolysis of MOF materials to achieve this goal of promoting NO adsorption is scarcely reported as far as we know. As shown in Fig. S7 (b), besides the surface sulfates (1344, 1261 and 1023 cm−1) and a small number of bulk sulfates (1090 cm−1), the main adsorbed NH3 species are NH4 + (1400–1500 cm−1) linked to B acid sites of HSO4 - (1261 cm−1), namely NH4HSO4. These results suggest that not only the HSO4 - can’t poison the active sites of Mn-MP catalysts for the adsorption and activation of NOx, but also it can serve as B acid sites for capturing NH3. In order to reveal the role of NH4HSO4, we then introduced NO/O2 through the S-Mn-MP pre-adsorbed by NH3 to test the reactivity of NH4HSO4. As shown in Fig. 14, The bands at 1430 (NH4 +), 1341 (surface sulfates) and 1252 (HSO4 -) cm−1 gradually disappeared with prolonging the exposure time to NO + O2, and meanwhile new peaks (1566 and 1252 cm−1) ascribed to the nitrates appeared, implying that the NH4 + linked to HSO4 - was consumed by NO with the HSO4 - reconversion to the surface sulfate. Thus, here we confirm that the NH4HSO4 is a reactive species for NH3-SCR of NOx, and the poisoning effect of HSO4 - on the catalyst is reversible, which contributes to the high SO2 tolerance of Mn-MP catalysts. Ye et al. [53] also found that NH4HSO4 can act as a reductant to react with NO. Therefore, as depicted in Fig. 15, the Mn-MP catalyst with a 3D porous structure and more L/B acid sites has a higher adsorption capacity for active intermediates (i.e. bidentate nitrate and adsorbed NH3 species) than the Mn-A catalyst. After introducing SO2 + O2, many active sites of the Mn-A catalyst are poisoned by the bulk MnSO4, resulting in the loss of adsorption capacity for both NH3 and NO. By contrast, over Mn-MP catalyst, the existence of B acid sites forms a barrier for active sites against the attack of SO2, reducing the formation of bulk MnSO4, therefore the active nitrate (i.e. bidentate nitrate) and NH4 + species can be involved in the NH3-SCR reaction. 4 Conclusions Herein we have developed a highly active low-temperature deNOx catalyst (Mn-MP) using PVP doping MOF as the precursor, and it also exhibited high SO2/H2O tolerance. Over the Mn-MP catalyst, more than 85% NOx conversion was achieved in the temperature range of 100–200 °C, and the NOx conversion can be maintained after exposure to SO2 or H2O. The formation of abundant acid sites, Mn4+ and surface chemical oxygen account for the enhanced catalytic activity of the Mn-MP catalyst. The formation of less bulk MnSO4 due to the B acid sites improves the adsorption of active intermediates (bidentate nitrate and NH4 +) in the presence of sulfate species, which is responsible for the high SO2 resistance of the Mn-MP catalyst in the SCR reaction. The present research provides new sights on the synthesis of MOF-Mn-derived materials with remarkable low-temperature NH3-SCR activity and high tolerance to SO2/H2O. coredata.dc:description: A novel MnOx catalyst (Mn-MP) derived from MOF-Mn3(BTC)2(H2O)6 was fabricated and investigated for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 at low temperatures. Mn-MP catalyst showed a superior activity and noticeably improved tolerance to SO2. The MOF precursor and doping PVP led to large surface area, small particle size and more crystalline defects of Mn-MP catalyst. The formation of abundant acid sites, Mn4+ and surface chemical oxygen would promote the NH3-SCR reaction. In situ DRIFTs demonstrated the high SO2 tolerance over the Mn-MP catalyst not only results from the reduced irreversible sulfurization rate, but also the promoting adsorption of active bidentate nitrates and NH4 + in the coexistence of sulfates. Our work shed light on the design of porous MOF-derived MnOx catalysts with high SO2 resistance at low temperatures.
coredata.dc:title: Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 over a novel MOF- derived MnOx catalyst
